quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The sacred cows are like their own roadmap. What are all the things that you think we're not allowed to change? Let's start there.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A practical framework for unlocking product progress by explicitly targeting “untouchable” assumptions as the starting point for a roadmap.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We wanted to change the lack of ambition, the lack of creativity, the lack of customers feeling that the product had changed at all.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Defines a clear, customer-perceived bar for product velocity and culture change: users must feel meaningful change, not just internal activity.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You're known for at Twitter someone that turned the culture of the product team and Twitter in general from a very stagnant, nothing-is-changing product to shipping all the time.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Captures the outcome metric of a successful product-org transformation: shifting from stagnation to consistent shipping.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I was like, "I might flame out completely, but Hell if I don't try."
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of the risk posture often required to break out of entrenched, risk-averse product cultures.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Enterpret unifies all of your customer interactions from Gong calls to Zendesk tickets to Twitter threads to app store reviews, and makes it available for your product team.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Enterpret read)
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable approach to centralizing disparate customer feedback sources into one system for product decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What makes Enterpret special is its ability to build customer-specific, adaptive AI models that provide the most granular and accurate categorization of all your customer feedback, and also connect customer feedback to revenue impact to help product leaders confidently prioritize things that will actually move the needle for your business.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Enterpret read)
quotes.context: Offers a prioritization methodology: categorize feedback at high granularity and tie it directly to revenue impact to guide roadmap choices.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Customers always seem to want to give you their data in the messiest possible CSV file, and building a spreadsheet importer becomes a never-ending sink for your engineering and support resources.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (OneSchema read)
quotes.context: A practical warning about the hidden, ongoing cost of building and maintaining CSV importers in SaaS products.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Customers get frustrated by useless messages like error on line 53 and never end up getting started with your product.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (OneSchema read)
quotes.context: Pinpoints a specific UX failure mode that directly harms activation: unhelpful import errors that block onboarding.

quotes.topic_title: Meeting Elon and Walter Isaacson present
quotes.text: So, the first time I ever met Elon was over at FaceTime where Elon was just very curious to ask, "Hey, you were at Twitter for a while. You seem to have done some things. What should I be digging into, and who I be talking to?"
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Highlights a practical onboarding approach for new leaders: quickly map what to investigate and which people to consult.

quotes.topic_title: Meeting Elon and Walter Isaacson present
quotes.text: I was scurried through the back door because I didn't want to make a scene and make it ... There was a lot of rumors around is Kayvon coming back, and I just wanted to avoid all of that.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A concrete example of managing organizational optics and rumor control during sensitive transitions.

quotes.topic_title: Meeting Elon and Walter Isaacson present
quotes.text: But he said nothing the entire time, and we had probably a two-hour conversation talking about the past, the future of Twitter, the good, the bad, the ugly.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Suggests a useful meeting format: cover past/future plus “good, bad, ugly” to surface reality quickly in high-stakes discussions.

quotes.topic_title: Meeting Elon and Walter Isaacson present
quotes.text: And I was like, "Oh, shit. I guess that whole conversation was on the record. I don't know."
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that “informal” conversations may effectively be public—assume you’re on the record in uncertain settings.

quotes.topic_title: Meeting Elon and Walter Isaacson present
quotes.text: but it was really bizarre and unique and surreal seeing that glimmer in someone else who was like, "Yeah, I also just bought this thing, so I can actually do whatever the Hell I want. And by the way, here's some crazy dreams I have for doing it."
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Captures a memorable product/strategy insight: ownership and mandate can radically expand the solution space and ambition.

quotes.topic_title: Did Kayvon influence Elon’s Twitter plans?
quotes.text: I think what we spent time talking about is I shared my perspective with him of people I thought who were exceptional, who were at the company, and if I was in his shoes, who I would spend time with and embrace.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Actionable leadership tactic: prioritize identifying and empowering exceptional internal leaders during transitions.

quotes.topic_title: Did Kayvon influence Elon’s Twitter plans?
quotes.text: Most of the people that I mentioned are still there, which is awesome, and they seem to be A, empowered, which is great, and B, having fun, which is awesome.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Concrete example of a positive outcome metric for org changes: retention plus empowerment and morale among key leaders.

quotes.topic_title: Did Kayvon influence Elon’s Twitter plans?
quotes.text: But I always felt really bullish on that being the future of essentially how content is moderated on Twitter, just because it was very clear that the way we were handling content moderation among many other flaws just wasn't scalable.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Scalability-driven product thesis: shift moderation toward systems that can scale beyond traditional approaches.

quotes.topic_title: Did Kayvon influence Elon’s Twitter plans?
quotes.text: My hope, having left the company and having had a new leader come in, was that those things would be given more oxygen.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Portfolio management insight: leadership change can be an opportunity to increase investment in promising initiatives rather than reset everything.

quotes.topic_title: Did Kayvon influence Elon’s Twitter plans?
quotes.text: Yeah, I think in that sense, I hope that our brainstorm was useful, but for all I know he doesn't even remember the conversation.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder: influence is uncertain—focus on sharing high-leverage inputs, not on getting credit or certainty of impact.

quotes.topic_title: How Kayvon was fired during paternity leave
quotes.text: I think if you're going to have a functional organization, you need to have a GM or a CEO who's extremely leaned-in to tiebreak and resolve conflict and make sure the team is moving quickly.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Clear operating model guidance: functional orgs require an active executive “tiebreaker” to prevent slow decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: How Kayvon was fired during paternity leave
quotes.text: And Jack, for all of his amazing qualities, just wasn't operating that way, and so you had a group of highly opinionated people that often disagreed and would create either the need for consensus or deadlock.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A concrete failure mode of functional structures: strong leaders without a decisive arbiter can drift into consensus-seeking or deadlock.

quotes.topic_title: How Kayvon was fired during paternity leave
quotes.text: It's very difficult to change culture with one hand tied behind your back.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Memorable reminder that culture change often requires full cross-functional ownership (not just PM) to be effective.

quotes.topic_title: How Kayvon was fired during paternity leave
quotes.text: The day after we get home from the hospital, Parag called me and said that he was letting me go and that he was taking the team in a different direction. That night, Twitter signed a term sheet with Elon to sell the company.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Specific timeline example showing how leadership decisions and major corporate events can collide abruptly, impacting individuals and teams.

quotes.topic_title: How Kayvon was fired during paternity leave
quotes.text: I think there was an incredible opportunity in that that now you have this organization and this product and this incredible ecosystem that can be devoid of all the political bullshit associated with being a public company.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Counterintuitive take: concentrated ownership can reduce governance/political overhead and increase product execution speed.

quotes.topic_title: Elon’s ‘come hang out’ product invitation
quotes.text: He was just like, "Do you want to just come? You seem like you care about the product, and you don't have dumb ideas. Do you want to come hang out?"
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Shows a founder’s informal bar for bringing in product talent—care deeply, avoid bad ideas—highlighting how hiring/roles can be fluid in high-change environments.

quotes.topic_title: Elon’s ‘come hang out’ product invitation
quotes.text: And he was like, "Don't know, just hang out, and you can swipe left or swipe right."
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A memorable metaphor for treating joining as a low-commitment trial, which can be a practical way to de-risk fit in ambiguous roles.

quotes.topic_title: Elon’s ‘come hang out’ product invitation
quotes.text: So, I ended up deciding that actually, I'm just ready. I'm ready to move on.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A clear decision rule practitioners can relate to: recognizing when your personal runway on a problem/company is exhausted even if new opportunities appear.

quotes.topic_title: Elon’s ‘come hang out’ product invitation
quotes.text: What I think about is there's always this tension being a PM at a company with a very strong-minded, product-oriented founder, and I feel like you would've been in the epitome worst possible situation there, where you're a product leader between Elon and the rest of org.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Names a common structural failure mode—product leadership caught between a forceful founder and the organization—useful as a diagnostic for role viability.

quotes.topic_title: Elon’s ‘come hang out’ product invitation
quotes.text: I don't have a canvas to try and exert my dreams on this place. I think Elon took that mantle, and I'm excited to see what he going to do with it is the feeling I had.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A counterintuitive but practical lens: when a new owner/founder takes the “vision mantle,” product leaders may lose the necessary autonomy (“canvas”) to be effective.

quotes.topic_title: From stagnant Twitter to shipping constantly
quotes.text: That first year of being the head of product was one of the most difficult of my career not because the work was difficult, but because it was so politically and bureaucratically exhausting to try and change culture in a way that just there wasn't alignment around.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Highlights that culture change often fails not on execution difficulty, but on misalignment and organizational friction.

quotes.topic_title: From stagnant Twitter to shipping constantly
quotes.text: But when you have to essentially drive consensus amongst your peers across the other functions, that's a different game. That's not execution. That's politics and consensus building.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A clear mental model distinguishing cross-functional alignment work from product execution work.

quotes.topic_title: From stagnant Twitter to shipping constantly
quotes.text: That first year of changing culture was like walking through mud, and it was really difficult.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A memorable description of the early phase of culture change that sets expectations for practitioners.

quotes.topic_title: From stagnant Twitter to shipping constantly
quotes.text: But I think my takeaway there is you can't change culture without having alignment from the top. It's difficult to change culture when you have a pocket of a company trying to advocate for change.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: culture change requires top-level sponsorship, not isolated team advocacy.

quotes.topic_title: From stagnant Twitter to shipping constantly
quotes.text: Literally the first two years I was at the company, the stated product strategy for Twitter was refine the core.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A concrete example of how an explicit strategy can bias an organization toward incrementalism over bold bets.

quotes.topic_title: Refine the core vs bold new bets
quotes.text: The reason why Twitter went from stagnant to declining DAU growth to growing DAU again is because they refined the core.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A concrete example that core iteration (not big new bets) can be the lever that restarts growth.

quotes.topic_title: Refine the core vs bold new bets
quotes.text: Now, that is not an inspiring product strategy. That does not result in the product feeling materially different or adding new capabilities, but it did return the company to user growth.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Highlights the tradeoff: optimization can drive metrics even when users don’t perceive meaningful change.

quotes.topic_title: Refine the core vs bold new bets
quotes.text: I think that in order to build something wonderful, you have to be a customer of the product.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A practitioner rule-of-thumb for product teams: firsthand usage is a prerequisite for high-quality decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Refine the core vs bold new bets
quotes.text: And the other thing I'll add to this is that there were so many sacred cows at Twitter that the sacred cows are their own roadmap. It's like a built-in free roadmap of like, all right, what are all the things that you think we're not allowed to change? Let's start there.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A memorable framework for finding high-leverage opportunities by targeting “untouchable” assumptions first.

quotes.topic_title: Sacred cows as a roadmap for innovation
quotes.text: And the other thing I'll add to this is that there were so many sacred cows at Twitter that the sacred cows are their own roadmap. It's like a built-in free roadmap of like, all right, what are all the things that you think we're not allowed to change? Let's start there.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A reusable innovation framework: treat “untouchable” assumptions as the highest-leverage starting points for experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Sacred cows as a roadmap for innovation
quotes.text: And the process of starting to address those one by one reveals a lot of the cultural hesitations that existed.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A diagnostic method: attempting to change sacred cows surfaces the real (often hidden) cultural blockers in an organization.

quotes.topic_title: Sacred cows as a roadmap for innovation
quotes.text: So that was like Twitter acting as policemen and policewoman, completely unscalable and challenging, especially in the context of someone replying to one of your tweets.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A concrete product insight: relying on centralized moderation for unwanted replies doesn’t scale, motivating user-level controls.

quotes.topic_title: Sacred cows as a roadmap for innovation
quotes.text: Don't work on this feature. This is bad for your career. This is not going to launch, and you don't want to work on this. You don't want to be seen as having worked on this.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A vivid example of how fear and status dynamics can suppress experimentation even on small, low-risk product bets.

quotes.topic_title: Sacred cows as a roadmap for innovation
quotes.text: As a microcosm for some of the cultural challenge we had around trying big, bold bets, which by the way, this wasn't even a big, bold bet. It was such an innocuous thing to try.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation: organizations can treat even innocuous experiments as taboo, signaling deeper cultural resistance to change.

quotes.topic_title: Portfolio approach: reliability plus new capabilities
quotes.text: One of the lines that we had to maneuver was creating a portfolio of bets where some of them were not speculative at all.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Introduces a practical portfolio approach to product strategy that deliberately mixes low-risk, high-certainty work with riskier bets.

quotes.topic_title: Portfolio approach: reliability plus new capabilities
quotes.text: We knew that if we continue to invest in ML and getting better with recommendations in the main feed and through notifications and things like improving the onboarding flow, it was rife with opportunity.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Highlights reliable growth levers (recommendations, notifications, onboarding) that teams can systematically improve for compounding gains.

quotes.topic_title: Portfolio approach: reliability plus new capabilities
quotes.text: And we found that in a couple countries, like we had a bug with our SMS verification flow where we wanted to verify users who were signing up with a phone number and our telco integration to send SMS verification cards just wasn't working.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A concrete example of how instrumentation can uncover basic funnel breakages that silently block growth.

quotes.topic_title: Portfolio approach: reliability plus new capabilities
quotes.text: And so a huge percentage of people signing up in the UAE and other countries just couldn't use Twitter.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A vivid data-like takeaway showing how a single reliability issue can wipe out adoption in entire markets.

quotes.topic_title: Portfolio approach: reliability plus new capabilities
quotes.text: But we wanted to balance that with a portfolio of other bets and product improvements that would materially add new capabilities.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Emphasizes the second half of the portfolio model: pairing foundational reliability work with capability-expanding investments.

quotes.topic_title: Using acquihires to drive bold initiatives
quotes.text: One, the only thing I'd add to what you said in terms of the ingredients, it was also just storytelling and just repetitive storytelling around this is the vision, these are the bets we're making. Here's why. And you can't just tell that story once.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Highlights a practical change-management tactic: repeat the vision and rationale internally (and not as a one-off) to build momentum and alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Using acquihires to drive bold initiatives
quotes.text: I think one of the really important things about driving cultural change at the leadership level is you've got to identify whether someone's on the wagon or off the wagon and either quickly convince them to get on the wagon or if they're not on the wagon, they shouldn't be there.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Provides a clear, memorable framework for leadership alignment and decisive team shaping during cultural change.

quotes.topic_title: Using acquihires to drive bold initiatives
quotes.text: But anyway, going to your question, one of the things we found that was a really effective way of accelerating cultural change and also helping drive some of these product initiatives that were particularly speculative was doing small acquires.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Shares a concrete methodology—small acquihires—as a lever to speed culture change and staff risky, high-variance bets.

quotes.topic_title: Using acquihires to drive bold initiatives
quotes.text: And that was a very speculative bet that by the way, a lot of people thought, most people thought was a terrible idea. We gave Keith a little silo to go build this vision, and then it was our job to make sure that bet didn't get suffocated in the context of a big organization that would otherwise have not had patience for it.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Counterintuitively argues that protecting controversial bets with a “silo” can be essential to prevent big-org processes from killing them early.

quotes.topic_title: Using acquihires to drive bold initiatives
quotes.text: So I feel like that we ended up realizing, both through the company's history and through learning, that this is actually a very effective way to drive cultural change and to deliver impact because you need a special type of person to be able to both operate within the existing structure and change the structure, to know when to use the system and to know when to fuck the system.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Captures the key talent profile for bold initiatives in large companies: founder-operators who can navigate and selectively bypass bureaucracy.

quotes.topic_title: Staffing: belief and obsession over availability
quotes.text: And imagine, it's hard enough to build something from nothing. It's even harder if the team doesn't believe in it. This is to the point of just being toxic.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Highlights the failure mode of staffing teams with people who lack conviction, especially on zero-to-one work.

quotes.topic_title: Staffing: belief and obsession over availability
quotes.text: The startup would never succeed if all the people who are working on that startup aren't to the point of being perhaps irrational obsessed with that idea.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Sets a high bar for commitment as a prerequisite for success on ambitious, uncertain projects.

quotes.topic_title: Staffing: belief and obsession over availability
quotes.text: you need to staff projects with the team of people that are well equipped from a skillset standpoint, but more importantly have an obsession with the idea they want to pursue.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Actionable staffing principle: prioritize belief/obsession over mere availability or even pure skill match.

quotes.topic_title: Staffing: belief and obsession over availability
quotes.text: Because every project, whether big or small, there is an element of you need to will this thing into existence because it's hard.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Memorable mental model for execution: progress often requires sustained force of will, not just planning.

quotes.topic_title: Staffing: belief and obsession over availability
quotes.text: a very easy cheat code for an organization to employ is to say, if you're going to work on something, especially if it's speculative or risky, staff it with a set of people who believe in it and really want to learn whether this solves a customer problem or not.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Provides a practical heuristic for staffing risky bets to avoid slow, demotivating execution.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're trying to build that kind of experience for your users, you need up to date, reliable information about what your users do in your product and why they do it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable product principle: great UX requires continuously reliable behavioral data plus understanding user motivation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Heap captures all of this user activity for you automatically and then gives you definitive answers to all your questions about user behavior in seconds, not weeks.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete claim about methodology/tooling: automate data capture to drastically shorten the insight cycle from weeks to seconds.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I feel like at Twitter, jobs-to-be-done was implemented so strictly that it burned a lot of people out on it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that even good frameworks can backfire when applied too rigidly, leading to burnout and backlash.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I was not a fan of how we leveraged jobs-to-be-done at Twitter. I thought it was exhausting and not particularly helpful, and so it's a particularly sore subject for me because I was sort of charged with defending it and rolling it out.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A practitioner’s critique that challenges conventional wisdom about JTBD, emphasizing the cost of forcing a framework that doesn’t fit.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-done backlash and framework fatigue
quotes.text: It's hard to do that when you don't really believe in something, but to me the critique is less about Jobs-to-be-Done though there are many critiques of it and more about every framework at its limit is followed to such a religious extent it's just unhelpful.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A contrarian warning that framework fatigue often comes from dogmatic over-application, not the framework itself.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-done backlash and framework fatigue
quotes.text: You need to have nuance in how you leverage these frameworks.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to treat frameworks as tools requiring judgment rather than rigid rules.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-done backlash and framework fatigue
quotes.text: Otherwise, you lose the forest through the trees and you end up following a process for the sake of following a process.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of how process can become performative and distract from outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-done backlash and framework fatigue
quotes.text: the premise of Jobs-to-be-Done and my most charitable take on Jobs-to-be-Done, which is actually useful is that it forces you to look at things through the lens of customers and understanding what their needs are and understanding what their true alternatives are outside of the narrow lens of your product.
quotes.speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
quotes.context: A practical framing of JTBD’s core value: expanding product thinking to customer needs and real-world alternatives.
